==Coptic== ===Etymology===
{{unc|cop}}. Either from {{inh|cop|egy|Íú•bw |a-b-db-nDs:Z2|tr={{m|egy|Íú•bw }}|dirth, filth; something bad}}, or from {{inh|cop|egx-dem|Íú£b, jÍú£b||to stamp cattle with branding mark}}, from {{inh|cop|egy|Íú£b|Ab-b-Q7|tr={{m|egy|Íú£b}}|branding mark}}.

Ultimately borrowed from {{bor|cop|sem-can|}} ''* æaby≈çn-'',<ref>{{cite-journal|last=Wilson-Wright|first=Aren M.|last2=Huehnergard|first2=John|title=How to Kill a Dragon in Northwest Semitic: Three Linguistic Observations regarding Ugaritic ltn and Hebrew liwyƒÅtƒÅn|journal=Vetus Testamentum|volume=72|issue=1|year=2021|doi=10.1163/15685330-bja10047|titleurl=https://brill.com/view/journals/vt/72/1/article-p151_8.xml|publisher=Brill|passage=Normally, the suffix ''*-ƒÅn'' becomes ''-√¥n'' in Biblical Hebrew with the operation of the Canaanite shift (e.g., ''* îabyƒÅn-'' > '' îeby√¥n'' ‚Äúpoor‚Äù).}}</ref>

Related to {{cog|uga|êéÄêéÅêéäêéê|t=poor, impoverished|ts= æabyƒÅnu}}.<ref>{{cite-book|last=Bordreuil|first=Pierre|last2=Pardee|first2=Dennis|title=A Manual of Ugaritic|page=293|text= æABYN adjective 'destitute, poor' / æabyƒÅnu/|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn= 1575066521|year=2009}}</ref><div>

* {{alter|cop|‚≤≠‚≤ó‚≤Åœ•‚≤ß||Bohairic}}

Also could be borrowed from {{bor|cop|grc|Œ∫Œ±ŒªœÖœÄœÑœåœÇ|t=covered}}, or from {{bor|cop|sem|-}}, as {{cog|syc|‹ü‹≤‹†‹µ‹ò‹µ‹ê|tr=kalƒÅwƒÅ}}, {{m|syc|‹ü‹≤‹†‹ò‹µ‹ê|tr=kalwƒÅ|t=tiara}} and {{cog|akk|íÜ™íáªíáª|ts=kul≈´lu|t=a kind of turban or headband}} have a similar meaning, however judging by {{cog|la|calautica}} already present in {{inh|cop|egx-dem|-}}.

etymologies.etymology_text:
==Coptic== ===Alternative forms=== * {{alter|cop|‚≤õ‚≤ì‚≤ô ‚≤°‚≤â ‚≤°‚≤â‚≤£‚≤Å‚≤õ||to a female, Bohairic}} * {{alter|cop|‚≤õ‚≤ì‚≤ô ‚≤°‚≤â ‚≤°‚≤ü‚≤©‚≤£‚≤Å‚≤õ||to a female, Sahidic}} ===Etymology===
From {{inh|cop|egy||n:y-G20-A2-r:N35-A2-k|tr={{m|egy|njm}} {{m|egy|rn}}{{m|egy|.k}}}}, with replacement of the possessive suffix .k ‚Äúyou‚Äù by the possessive adjective {{inh|cop|egy||G40-i-i-k|tr={{m|egy|pÍú£y}}{{m|egy|.k}}}} and the addition of the copula ‚≤°‚≤â derived from {{inh|cop|egy||G40-i-i|tr={{m|egy|pÍú£y}}}}.
===Phrase=== {{head|cop|phrase}} # [[what is your name]]? #* Genesis 32:27 (Bohairic) #*: ‚≤°‚≤âœ´‚≤Åœ• ‚≤á‚≤â ‚≤õ‚≤Åœ• œ´‚≤â '''‚≤õ‚≤ì‚≤ô ‚≤°‚≤â ‚≤°‚≤â‚≤ï‚≤£‚≤Å‚≤õ''' #*:: "But he said to him, 'What is your name?'" #* Luke 8:30 (Sahidic) #*: ‚≤Å ‚≤ì‚≤• œ´‚≤õ‚≤ü‚≤©œ• œ´‚≤â '''‚≤õ‚≤ì‚≤ô ‚≤°‚≤â ‚≤°‚≤â‚≤ï‚≤£‚≤Å‚≤õ''' #*:: "Jesus asked him, 'What is your name?'" ====Usage notes==== ‚≤õ‚≤ì‚≤ô ‚≤°‚≤â ‚≤°‚≤â‚≤ï‚≤£‚≤Å‚≤õ (lit.Àê Who your name) and its feminine variants are the standard way to express "What is your name", "What are you called" in Coptic. Under the influence of modern languages like English, *‚≤Åœ£ ‚≤°‚≤â ‚≤°‚≤â‚≤ï‚≤£‚≤Å‚≤õ (lit.: "What is your name") has become common in revivalist circles. This is, however, not the regular expression in Coptic materials from the time when Coptic was still actively written by native speakers.

‚≤õ‚≤ü‚≤ô‚≤ß‚≤â.references: * TLA lemma no. C2479 (‚≤õ‚≤ü‚≤ô‚≤ß‚≤â), in: Coptic Dictionary Online, ed. by the Koptische/Coptic Electronic Language and Literature International Alliance (KELLIA), https://coptic-dictionary.org/entry.cgi?tla=C2479 (accessed 2024-09-16).

definitions: [Sahidic] Nu, the egyptian god of primeval abyss.

From {{inh|cop|egx-dem|s-·∏•mt||woman}}, from {{inh|cop|egy|zt-·∏•mt||woman}}, from {{m|egy|zt|z:t*B1|tr={{m|egy|zt}}|woman}} + {{m|egy|·∏•mt|N41:t-B1|tr={{m|egy|·∏•mt}}|wife, woman}}, a compound that arose because the feminine ending {{m|egy|-t}} in {{m|egy|zt}} eventually became silent, making {{m|egy|zt}} homophonous with {{m|egy|z||man}}, so that it became necessary to add {{m|egy|·∏•mt}} to clarify.

"Do you believe, King Agrippa, in the prophets? I know that you do believe."
"On the road at midday I saw, O King, a light from heaven, brighter than the brightness of the sun, shining round about me and those who journeyed with me.".

And Festus said, "King Agrippa and all men who are here present with us, you see this man about whom all the multitude of the Jews have applied to me, both at Jerusalem and also here, crying out that he ought not to live any longer."
When King Herod heard this, he was troubled, and all of Jerusalem with him.
While Paul answered for himself: "Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor yet against Caesar."
The Martyrdom of John of Phanijoit
"... on the Ô¨Åfth day, in the sixth hour, before sultan al-Kamil, son of sultan al-Adil, the Arab Persian on the throne of Piwan (Aywan)..."

Two wings of the great eagle were given to the woman, that she might fly into the wilderness to her place, so that she might be nourished for a time, and times, and half a time, from the face of the serpent.

===Etymology===
From the stem {{m|cop||œ≠‚≤Å‚≤•-}} of {{compound|cop|œ≠‚≤ì‚≤•‚≤ì|œ©‚≤ë‚≤ü|pos1=verb|pos2=noun|gloss1=become, be high|gloss2=horse}}, thus ‚Äúwho mounts a horse‚Äù.

==Coptic==

===Alternative forms===
* {{alter|cop|œ≠‚≤Å‚≤ß||Akhmimic|Fayyumic}}

===Etymology===
From {{inh|cop|egx-dem|qd||substance, character, form}}, from {{inh|cop|egy|qdy||substance, character, form}}. This etymology, however, is rejected by Carsten (1999: 108). He argues that a change from masculine to feminine is unlikely, and the fact that "qd" ceased to be used in Demotic in later times.<ref>{{cite-book|year=1999|author=Peust Carsten|title=Egyptian phonology|url=108}}</ref>

===Pronunciation===
* {{IPA|cop|/Ààk ≤ot/}}
